section.title: going to: positive sentences
section.sectiontitle: In the positive, we use subject + be + going to + verb. We usually use the short form of be.
section.text1: I'm going to visit my grandmother in hospital tomorrow.
section.text1a: You're going to wear a jacket.
section.text2: He/She's going to relax at home this weekend.
section.text2a: They're going to drive to the airport.

section.title: going to: negative sentences
section.sectiontitle: In the negative, we use subject + be + not going to + verb. We usually use the short form of be.
section.text1: I'm not going to wear a jumper tonight.
section.text1a: You're not going to stay with friends.
section.text2: He/She's not going to buy a mobile phone.
section.text2a: We're not going to stay in a hotel in Rome.

section.title: going to: question forms
section.sectiontitle: In the question form, we use question word + be + subject + going to + verb.
section.text1: What are they going to do tomorrow?
section.text1a: When are you going to buy the furniture?
section.text2: Who is she going to meet this evening?
section.text2a: Where is he going to go skiing?
section.sectiontitle2: We also use (be) going to with yes/no questions.
section.text3: Are they going to buy the house? Yes, they are.
section.text3a: Are you going to wear those boots? No, I'm not.
